explanation:
Altitude alerting occurs when approaching or departing the MCPâ€“selected altitude. Altitude alerting is inhibited when trailing edge flaps are extended to 25 or greater, or while G/S is captured.

---

variant.question: Altitude alerting occurs when approaching or departing from the MCP selected altitude.  When is the altitude alerting system inhibited?

options.text: Leading edge flaps are extended to 25 or greater
Landing gear is down and locked.
Glide slope is captured, or trailing edge flaps are extended to 25 or greater.
Leading edge flaps are extended to 25 or greater and the landing gear is extended.

variant.question: In Flight, the Intuvue radar will provide a windshear warning from 0.5nm to 3nm ahead of the aircraft.
When carrying out the Stall Warning Test, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The test cannot be completed until the DC Busses have been powered for up to 4 minutes.
The test cannot be completed until the AC Transfer Busses have been powered for up to 4 minutes.
The test can be completed on DC power
The test can be completed once AC power is available

variant.question: How can the Fire Warning Bell be silenced on the flight deck?

options.text: Fire bell can only be silenced by pressing either master fire warn light.
Push the master fire warn lights, press the horn cutout of the APU ground control panel, push fire warning bell cutout switch.
Push the master fire warn lights, push fire warning bell cutout switch.
Push the Master Fire Warn lights, press the Horn Cutout of the APU Ground Control Panel.

variant.question: The predictive windshear symbol radials, which extend from the predictive winsdshear symbol to help identify the location of a windshear event, are displayed in what colours?

options.text: Red and Black banded.
Amber.
Displayed amber when a predictive winshear caution is active, and displayed red when a predictive windshear warning is active.
Red.

variant.question: The PSEU light will illuminate along with a Master Caution and an OVERHEAD annunciator light, under which of the following situations?

options.text: Illuminates 30 seconds after the ground/air system senses ground mode, if an emergency exit flight lock has failed locked or a fault is detected.
Illuminates whenever ground/air system senses air mode, and an emergency exit flight lock has failed locked.
Illuminates 30 seconds after the ground/air system senses air mode, if an emergency exit flight lock has failed locked or a fault is detected.
Illuminates as soon as the ground/air system senses ground mode, if an emergency exit flight lock has failed locked or a fault is detected.

variant.question: As well as providing outputs for all stall warnings, the SMYD computers also provide outputs for GPWS Windshear Detection and Alert.
When an Annunciator Panel is pressed, all lights on both panel initially illuminate.
Which systems does the Proximity Switch Electronic Unit (PSEU) monitor

options.text: Takeoff/Landing Configuration Warnings, Landing Gear and Air/Ground sensing.
Air/Ground sensing, Landing Gear and Air/Ground sensing.
Takeoff/Landing Configuration Warnings, Landing Gear and Anti-Skid
Air/Ground sensing, Landing Gear and Anti-Skid.

variant.question: What does the TCAS Symbol that is a solid amber circle indicate?

options.text: Advises of traffic with potential impact in 40 seconds.
Advises that the proximate traffic is descending at more than 500 fpm.
Results in aural alert of "TRAFFIC, TRAFFIC" when within 6nm with 1200 feet or less of vertical seperation of other traffic.
Advises of traffic with potential impact on 25 seconds.

variant.question: The Stall Warning requirement is determined by what system component?

options.text: A single stall management configuration computer.
Two independent ADIRUs.
The Captain's or F/O's Alpha Vane.
Two independent SMYD Computers.

variant.question: Which two displays cannot be selected and shown simultaneously on the Navigation DU?

options.text: Terrain and TCAS.
Weather and Data.
Weather and Terrain.
TCAS and Airport.

explanation:
---

The Stall warning system consists of a stick shaker. The Clacker is the overspeed warning system.

variant.question: The stall warning test can only be carried out on the ground, the No1 and No2 systems must be carried out separately to ensure the clacker sounds when each system is tested.
The GPWS will provide an aural alert of "BANK ANGLE, BANK ANGLE" under which of the following circumstances?

options.text: Whenever trailing edge flaps are at 1 or greater and roll angle exceeds 35 degrees.
Whenever the bank angle exceeds the setting on the Bank Angle Selector.
When roll angle exceeds the maximum of 45 degrees.
When roll angle exceeding 35, 40 and 45 degrees.

variant.question: What is significant about the layout of the Annunciator Panel lights.

options.text: The lights are arranged in no significant order.
The lights on the Captain's side show the systems that the Captain is responsible for monitoring, and the lights of the F/Os side show the systems the F/O is responsible for monitoring.
The lights are arranged in order of priority to be dealt with in case of multiple system failures.
The lights are arranged to reflect the position of the systems panels on the Overhead Panels.

variant.question: With both engines operating and one forward thrust lever set below approximately 20 degrees thrust lever angle, the landing gear warning horn can be silenced with the landing gear warning HORN CUTOUT switch:

options.text: with flaps UP through 10 if below 800 feet RA and above 300 feet RA
with flaps UP through 10 if below 800 feet RA and above 200 feet RA
with flaps UP through 25 if below 800 feet RA and above 200 feet RA
it cannot be silenced if the thrust lever angle is less than 20 degrees.

variant.question: What is the first Radio Altitude Callout given during the approach?

options.text: 1000 feet - "One Thousand".
50 feet - "Fifty".
2450 feet - "Twenty Five Hundred".
2500 feet  - "Twenty Five Hundred".

variant.question: Altitude alerting, consisting of a tone and highlighted boxes, occurs at a set distance before reaching the selected attitude.  How many feet before the selected altitude do the altitude alert highlighted boxes no longer show?

options.text: 3000 fpm with 3000 feet to go, 2000 fpm with 2000 feet to go, 1000 fpm with 1000 feet to go.
300 feet
900 feet
600 feet

variant.question: Once an alert has occurred for deviating from the selected altitude, how is it cancelled?

options.text: Return to within 200 feet of selected altitude.
Press ALT INT to select next FMC target altitude.
Return to within 200 feet of selected altitude and press the HORN CUTOUT button on the Control Stand.
return to within 300 feet of selected altitude or deviate by more than 900 feet from selected altitude, or select a new altitude.

variant.question: The EGPWS contains a terrain database, which it uses for look-ahead terrain alerting.  Which of the following statements is correct for this terrain database?

options.text: All man-made obstructions are accounted for in the detailed areas of the EGPWS terrain database in areas close to major airports.
All EGPWS terrain databases account for man-made obstructions over 100 feet high, throughout the whole database area.
Man-made obstructions are not accounted for in all EGPWS terrain databases
All EGPWS terrain databases account for man-made obstructions over 100 feet high, in the more detailed areas of the database near major airports.

variant.question: The predictive windshear aural alerts will be heard through flightdeck speakers and the headsets at a pre-set volume.  They cannot be controlled or turned off by the crew.
The PSEU light, located on the forward overhead panel, will illuminate on the ground if a fault is detected in the PSEU or if an overwing exit flight lock fails to disengage when commanded.
When will the landing gear config warning horn give an intermittent warning sound?

options.text: Flaps 1 through 10, below 800 feet RA, either forward thrust lever at 20 degrees or less (or less than 34 degrees if only 1 engine running).
Flaps up through 10, below 800 feet RA, either forward thrust lever at 20 degrees or less (or less than 34 degrees if only 1 engine running).
Never
Flaps greater than 25, below 800 feet RA, regardless of forward thrust lever position.

variant.question: At what altitude (in feet) do the RA callouts begin?

options.text: ONE THOUSAND.
TWENTY FIVE HUNDRED.
TWO THOUSAND
FIFTEEN HUNDRED.

variant.question: The EGPWS displays terrain within 2,500 feet of the aircraft barometric altitude on the Navigation display.
How are crew alerted to a deviation from the selected altitude?

options.text: A warning tone sounds once deviation is 300 feet from selected altitude, the current altitude box turns amber and begins to flash.
A warning tone sounds once deviation is 300 feet from selected altitude, the current altitude box begins to flash.
A warning tone sounds once deviation is 300 feet from selected altitude, the current altitude box turns red and begins to flash.
A warning tone sounds once deviation is 900 feet from selected altitude, the current altitude box turns red and begins to flash.

variant.question: The TCAS system generates a Traffic Advisory, whenever another aircraft is what distance from point of closest approach?

options.text: <6 nm separation with < 1200 feet vertical separation.
>6 nm separation with >1200 feet vertical separation.
25 seconds.
40 seconds.

variant.question: At what altitude are the TCAS INCREASE DESCENT RAs inhibited?

options.text: 1,100 feet AGL.
1500 feet RA.
1500 feet AGL
1,100 feet RA.

variant.question: When configured for landing, the GPWS will NOT alert if attempting an off-airport landing.
How far from projected impact will the "TERRAIN, TERRAIN, PULL UP" aural warning be given?

options.text: 1.2 nm to 1.5 nm
1.2nm to 1.5nm or 20 to 30 seconds whichever limit occurs first.
Whenever descending below unsafe RA while too far from any airport in the terrain database.
20 to 30 seconds.

variant.question: Crew are warned of exceeding the maximum allowed airspeed by which of the following?

options.text: Aural Clacker, speedtape red and black band.
Aural Clacker, speedtape red and black band, speedtape amber band, stick shaker.
Aural Clacker, speedtape red and black band, stick shaker.
Aural Clacker.

variant.question: The Stall Warning System Stick Shaker can be tested by pressing the STALL WARNING TEST buttons on the AFT overhead panel.  Pressing No1 switch will activate the Captain's Stick Shaker and the Captain's column will vibrate.  Pressing N02 switch will activate the FO's Stick Shaker and the FO's column will vibrate.
What is the direct result of low oil pressure in the No2 IDG?

options.text: No immediate affect noticeable as the Bus Tie Brakers (BTB) automatically connect the No1 IDG to drive both AC Transfer Bus 1 and AC Transfer Bus 2.
Power automatically trips to the STANDBY system.
Power is lost on the First Officer's displays after a delay of 5 minutes.
The No2 Drive light illuminates amber.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is true for the CABIN ALTITUDE Warning?

options.text: A steady warning horn sounds and the amber CABIN ALTITUDE lights illuminate when the cabin altitude exceeds 14000 feet.
An intermittent warning horn sounds and the red CABIN ALTITUDE lights illuminate when the cabin altitude exceeds 10000 feet
A steady warning horn sounds and the red CABIN ALTITUDE warning lights illuminate when the cabin altitude exceeds 14000 feet.
An intermittent warning horn sounds and the amber CABIN ALTITUDE warning lights illuminate when the cabin altitude exceeds 10000 feet

variant.question: Pushing the ground proximity BELOW G/S P-INHIBIT light cancels or inhibits the alert when below 1,000 feet RA.
When testing the Mach/Airspeed warning system in flight, the No1 and No2 systems must be tested separately to identify that the clacker sounds for both systems independently.
